questions.q: In horticultural labels, “full sun” typically means:
questions.explain: Most plant labels and extension references use full sun as at least about 6 hours of direct sunlight.

questions.q: “Part shade” most often describes a site with:
questions.explain: Part shade commonly means some direct sun (often morning) but protection from intense afternoon sun.

questions.q: What does “well-drained soil” mean in practice?
choices: Excess water drains while soil stays evenly moist
questions.explain: Well-drained soils allow excess water to move through while still holding moisture for roots.

questions.q: Which soil texture generally holds the most water?
questions.explain: Clay’s very small particles and high surface area allow it to retain more water.

questions.q: Soil compaction most directly harms plants by reducing:
questions.explain: Compaction reduces pore space, limiting oxygen diffusion to roots and water infiltration.

questions.q: A reliable way to understand soil pH is that it affects:
choices: How available nutrients are to plants
questions.explain: Soil pH strongly influences nutrient availability and uptake, even if nutrients are present.

questions.q: Overwatering most commonly damages plants because it:
questions.explain: Saturated soils displace oxygen; roots can suffocate and become susceptible to rot.

questions.q: Which is the most reliable indicator that a plant needs watering?
questions.explain: Check soil moisture below the surface; wilting can occur from heat stress even when soil is moist.

questions.q: For many landscapes, the most efficient irrigation timing is:
questions.explain: Early morning reduces evaporation and leaf wetness duration compared to night watering.

questions.q: When planting a tree, the root flare should be:
choices: At or slightly above finished grade
questions.explain: Planting too deep is a leading failure cause; the root flare should be visible at/above grade.

questions.q: A good planting hole for a tree is generally:
choices: As deep as the root ball and 2–3× as wide
Same width as the root ball
questions.explain: Depth should match the root ball; a wide hole encourages lateral root expansion.

questions.q: After planting, the most important immediate care is usually:
questions.explain: Establishment success depends heavily on consistent, deep watering (not fertilizer) early on.

questions.q: The main benefit of mulch around plants is to:
questions.explain: Mulch moderates temperature, reduces evaporation, and suppresses weeds.

questions.q: Mulch should be kept away from direct contact with tree trunks to prevent:
questions.explain: Mulch piled against trunks traps moisture and encourages decay and pests (“mulch volcano”).

questions.q: A typical recommended mulch depth for many landscapes is about:
questions.explain: Around 2–3 inches is commonly recommended; too deep can reduce oxygen and hold excess moisture.

questions.q: The safest general time to prune many deciduous trees is:
questions.explain: Dormant pruning reduces stress and is often less favorable for many pathogens and insects.

questions.q: Why should you avoid leaving a long stub when pruning a branch?
choices: It prevents callus formation and can decay
questions.explain: Stubs don’t seal properly and can die back and decay, creating entry points for pests and disease.

questions.q: If a shrub blooms on old wood (forms buds the previous season), a general pruning rule is to prune:
questions.explain: Pruning right after flowering avoids removing next season’s flower buds formed on old wood.

questions.q: Excessive fertilizer can harm plants primarily by:
choices: Root burn and disrupted water uptake
questions.explain: High salts from overfertilization can damage roots and interfere with water absorption.

questions.q: On a fertilizer label like 10-10-10, the numbers represent:
questions.explain: The numbers indicate the percent of nitrogen, phosphorus (as phosphate), and potassium (as potash).

questions.q: Which is the best first step before deciding to fertilize a landscape?
questions.explain: Soil tests guide whether nutrients are needed and help avoid over-application.

questions.q: Photosynthesis primarily uses sunlight to convert:
choices: Carbon dioxide and water into sugars
questions.explain: Photosynthesis uses CO₂ and water to produce sugars (chemical energy), releasing oxygen as a byproduct.

questions.q: Transpiration is best described as:
choices: Water loss from leaves that helps move water/nutrients
questions.explain: Transpiration is water vapor loss through stomata; it drives water movement through the plant.

questions.q: Stomata are primarily responsible for:
questions.explain: Stomata open/close to regulate CO₂ intake and water loss.

questions.q: Chlorosis is most often seen as:
questions.explain: Chlorosis is yellowing from reduced chlorophyll, often tied to nutrient issues or pH-related lockout.

questions.q: Leaf scorch usually refers to:
choices: Brown, dry leaf margins from stress
questions.explain: Scorch commonly appears as browning at edges/tips from water stress, heat, salt, or root damage.

questions.q: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) emphasizes:
choices: Monitoring and using least-disruptive controls first
questions.explain: IPM focuses on scouting, thresholds, and targeted controls to minimize impacts and resistance.

questions.q: Many foliar fungal diseases spread most easily when leaves are:
questions.explain: Leaf wetness duration is a key driver for many fungal and bacterial infections.

questions.q: Aphids often cause which symptom on new growth?
questions.explain: Aphids feed on sap, distorting tender growth and excreting honeydew that can lead to sooty mold.

questions.q: Powdery mildew is typically recognized by:
questions.explain: Powdery mildew looks like a white/gray coating and often occurs with humid air and moderate temps.

questions.q: Why is it generally better to water at the soil level rather than overhead for many plants?
choices: It reduces leaf wetness and disease risk
questions.explain: Overhead watering can keep foliage wet longer, promoting foliar diseases.

questions.q: A key reason weeds thrive in thin turf is:
choices: Bare soil and low competition from grass
questions.explain: Weeds exploit open space; dense turf shades soil and competes effectively for resources.

questions.q: Preemergent herbicides primarily target weeds by:
questions.explain: Preemergents act on germinating seeds/seedlings; timing before germination is essential.

questions.q: Asexual (vegetative) propagation produces plants that are:
questions.explain: Cuttings/division/layering typically produce clones with the same genetics as the parent plant.

questions.q: Which method is commonly used to propagate many houseplants quickly?
questions.explain: Stem cuttings are a common, efficient method for many houseplants.

questions.q: Cold stratification is used to:
choices: Break seed dormancy in some species
questions.explain: Some seeds require a moist chilling period to break dormancy and germinate reliably.

questions.q: “Hardening off” seedlings means:
choices: Gradually acclimating plants to outdoor conditions
questions.explain: Hardening off reduces transplant shock by slowly increasing sun, wind, and temperature exposure.

questions.q: A common reason container plants fail is:
questions.explain: Containers must drain well; waterlogged media quickly leads to root stress and rot.

questions.q: Why do container plants typically need more frequent watering than in-ground plants?
choices: Potting mixes drain faster and have less total soil volume
Roots don’t absorb water in pots
Mulch can’t be used in pots
questions.explain: Less volume and faster drainage mean containers dry out more quickly than ground soil.

questions.q: Finished compost is best described as:
choices: Stable, dark organic matter with earthy smell
questions.explain: Finished compost is decomposed, stable organic material that improves soil structure and biology.

questions.q: A good compost pile generally needs:
choices: A mix of greens and browns plus moisture and oxygen
questions.explain: Composting works best with balanced carbon/nitrogen inputs, adequate moisture, and oxygen.

questions.q: The single best cultural practice to reduce many turf problems is:
choices: Mowing at the correct height for the species
questions.explain: Proper mowing height supports deeper roots and denser turf, suppressing weeds and stress.

questions.q: Why is frequent shallow watering discouraged for lawns?
choices: It encourages shallow roots and increases stress susceptibility
questions.explain: Shallow watering promotes shallow roots; deeper, less frequent watering generally builds resilience.

questions.q: Why is staking a newly planted tree often unnecessary or limited in duration?
choices: It makes the trunk too flexible
It can reduce trunk strength development if left too long
questions.explain: Some movement helps trunks strengthen; prolonged staking can lead to weak trunks and girdling ties.

questions.q: Girdling roots are problematic because they can:
choices: Constrict water/nutrient flow and destabilize the tree
questions.explain: Roots circling and tightening around the trunk can restrict vascular flow and weaken stability over time.

questions.q: “Rejuvenation pruning” on some shrubs generally involves:
choices: Cutting many stems down near the base to renew growth
questions.explain: Many multi-stem shrubs can be renewed by removing older stems near the base to stimulate new shoots.

questions.q: Nitrogen deficiency most commonly shows as:
questions.explain: Nitrogen is mobile in plants, so deficiency symptoms often appear first on older leaves.

questions.q: Iron deficiency commonly appears as:
choices: Yellowing between veins on newest leaves
questions.explain: Iron is relatively immobile; deficiency often shows as interveinal chlorosis on young leaves.

questions.q: Why do plants often wilt in hot afternoon sun even when soil is moist?
questions.explain: High heat and sun increase transpiration; plants may wilt temporarily even with adequate soil moisture.

questions.q: What is the primary reason frost can injure tender plants?
choices: Ice formation damages plant cells and tissues
questions.explain: Freezing can rupture cells and disrupt tissues; tender plants lack cold hardiness.

questions.q: A key first step in diagnosing a plant problem is to:
choices: Correctly identify the plant and observe symptoms/patterns
questions.explain: Accurate identification and pattern observation are foundational; treatment depends on correct diagnosis.
